summary: This document is an email chain from February 2019 discussing a meeting to review a potential sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email, forwarded on February 24, 2019, references a pitch made earlier that week by lawyers, including Pete Skinner, representing a victim who was 16 at the time of the alleged abuse. The email notes Epstein's history, his 2007 non-prosecution agreement, and the complexity of the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a financier with multiple homes, accused of sex trafficking with dozens of victims, and subject of a 2007 non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Pete Skinner
persons.context: One of the lawyers who came in earlier in the week to pitch a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein.

connections.description: Pete Skinner, as a lawyer, is pitching a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein on behalf of a victim.

events.title: Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Lawyer Pitch on Epstein Case
events.description: Earlier in the week of February 24, 2019, Pete Skinner and two other lawyers pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York.

keyFacts: Lawyers, including Pete Skinner, pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York in February 2019.
The case involved a victim who was 16 years old at the time she was allegedly prostituted by Epstein.
Epstein was described as having 'dozens of victims' and it was unclear if his criminal conduct had stopped.
The email notes the existence of a 2007 non-prosecution agreement between Epstein and the Southern District of Florida U.S. Attorney's Office.
The facts of the case were described as 'complicated' with several related civil cases.
